2025-03-28 15:30: Friday update time:

one more week to go. Lecture is on multiway frequency tables, as analyzed by log-linear models. I like to end with this because it has a lot in common with regression, so many of the ideas are familiar (though there are one or two that are not).
solutions to last week’s worksheet, and a worksheet for the upcoming week are on the worksheets page.
More practice problems in PASIAS chapter 42.
Final exam is on April 12. I will post an announcement on Quercus with where and exactly when. I will have extra office hours sometime during the week before (thinking probably Wednesday).

2025-03-24 12:20: a couple of notes:

Assignment 8 is closed. My solutions to it are on the assignment solutions page.
If your final exam mark is higher than your midterm mark, the final counts instead of the midterm.

2025-03-21 16:00: Friday update:

Assignment 8 and last is due tonight. My solutions to Assignment 7 are up on the assignment solutions page.
My solutions to Worksheet 10 are up on the worksheets page.
Next week’s lectures are on drawing maps and principal components. I don’t think we’ll have time to get to factor analysis this time around, but the ideas there should make sense once we have studied principal components. There is a worksheet 11 up on those.
PASIAS chapter 38 on maps and chapter 40 on principal components.

2025-03-19 13:20:

thanks to the student who found a discrepancy in the discriminant analysis lecture notes. I went through those notes and the cluster analysis ones (where I feared there would be similar problems), and the versions of those two sets of slides on the lecture notes page should now be correct.
I think I am now up to date on all the appeals and Quercus discussion board posts.

2025-03-17 10:45: we have midterm marks!

my solutions
stats: Q3 52 (78%), median 45.5 (68%), Q1 37 (55%). These are about in line with historical averages for my exams.
you will see your mark on Quercus shortly
you will get an email from Crowdmark with instructions for accessing your marked exam in it. If you have not earned full marks for a question, you should have a comment from the grader on your marked exam; that, plus a review of my solutions, should help you understand why you did not earn full marks.
I am happy that the graders have marked consistently and in accordance with my solutions, and therefore I am not allowing appeals of the midterm marks. The marking is, if anything, generous. You should be able to answer any questions about the marking by carefully reading the grader’s comments and carefully reading my solutions.

2025-03-16 20:30: the exam is now at 97% marked, just part of question 14 left.
2025-03-15 10:45: your TAs had a busy Friday, and we are now all the way to 90% done marking the midterm.
2025-03-14.159265359: happy pi day!

Midterm marking is now 60% done.
Lectures next week are on cluster analysis. I think we are on course to finish everything: maps (maybe) and principal components the week after next, multiway frequency tables in the last week. (Yes, we are that near the end.)
PASIAS for cluster analysis: chapters 36 and 37.
Assignments: assignment 7 is due tonight; assignment 8 opens today and is due on Mar 21.
Assignment 8 is based on worksheets 8 and 9. There is also a worksheet 10, which is on the worksheets page, along with solutions to worksheet 9.
Now I need to get back to marking exams!

2025-03-13 21:15: we are past halfway, 55% done as I write.
2025-03-12 22:00: there is a limit to how much exam marking I can do on a lecture day, and I have reached it. Exam is 40% marked.
2025-03-11 22:30: midterm is 25% marked, and I am out of juice.
2025-03-11 11:45:

assignment 6 is marked, grades being posted shortly. Appeals by usual procedure between Mar 14 and 21 inclusive.
I have looked at all the appeals for assignment 3. The other appeals will have to wait until I have finished marking my share of the midterms.
as of right now, we are 10% done marking the midterms (I have marked two more questions this morning).

2025-03-10 23:00: The exams are scanned and on Crowdmark. We are now at the dizzying heights of 3% done (meaning, I have marked one question). I was going to do a second one tonight, but I ran out of juice. Tomorrow, I am hoping to make some decent progress.
2025-03-08 13:30: the update turned out to be so late that it is now Saturday!

The midterm will be scanned on (probably) Monday, and marking will begin after that. I may not have much time this coming week outside of lectures because I will be marking my share of your midterm.
Now that you have written the exam, you can get back to the repeated measures material. There is a worksheet 8 on the worksheets page about that; the answers are also up. (There is also a worksheet 9 on the upcoming week’s material.)
Next week’s lecture is on discriminant analysis. This is the natural followup to MANOVA; you’ll remember that MANOVA doesn’t tell us much beyond “there is something going on”, and discriminant analysis will help you discover what the “something” is.
Assignment 7 is due on March 14. Assignment 8 opens on that day, and is due on March 21. Assignment 8 is on the material in worksheets 8 and 9. There are no more assignments after that. (I appreciate that you may have term papers and the like that are due at the end of classes, and I don’t want to be part of that problem.) There will be worksheets the rest of the way to help you practice what you have learned.
If you want extra practice, PASIAS is the place to look:

Chapter 33 is MANOVA
Chapter 34 is repeated measures
Chapter 35 is discriminant analysis.


2025-03-07 17:30: A very late Friday update (which I will add to later):

Midterm exam tonight! See the Quercus announcement for place and time (we are in two rooms, so make sure you are in the correct one). If you miss the midterm for any reason, the weight goes onto the final exam. I do not need documentation for this.

2025-03-05 17:00: Assignment 6 solutions are up on the assignment solution page.
2025-03-05 13:10: I have just updated the MANOVA and repeated measures lecture notes:

there was a question on Monday about Box’s M test for interactions (in the peanuts example). I have added a little about this to the lecture notes, and put a more detailed answer on the Quercus discussion board.
I fitted the mixed model (for the dogs) wrong in repeated measures. I used time (quantitative) in my model, which assumes a linear relationship with time. This is not what I wanted; I wanted to see whether there was any relationship with time (or any interaction between time and drug), so the right way is to treat time as categorical, which is done using the “temporary” column I called timex. The results from the mixed model are now more or less consistent with the MANOVA approach, which is how it should be.
The revised slides (for both) are now on the lecture notes page.
I will (hopefully) give the Monday folks a brief summary next week of what changed. However, you may need to remind me, because this is exactly the kind of thing I tend to forget!

2025-02-28 11:10 with additions 2025-03-03 11:15: Friday update (back to the usual day this week):

reminder of midterm on Mar 7:

See Quercus announcement for time, place, and details. One thing I forgot to mention: the rules for the exams in this course are the same as for STAC32: bring any printed material you like, but make sure it’s organized, or else you will waste too much time looking things up.
material on the midterm is everything up to and including last week’s lecture. Last week’s (Thursday) update will tell you what that is.
the midterm has gone for printing. It has 6 scenarios with 30 questions total, worth a total of 67 marks.
(added 2025-03-03 11:15) other exam rules for this course are the same as for STAC32. In particular, if you miss the midterm (for any reason), the weight is transferred to the final exam.

Assignments:

Assignment 4 is graded, and the marks will be posted shortly. (Added 2025-03-03 11:15: I forgot to post the marks, but they are posted now.) Appeals by usual procedure between Mar 5 and Mar 12.
Assignment 6 is due tonight and is open until Sunday night (with late penalty).
Assignment 7 (on the same material as Worksheet 7) will open today, but is not due until Mar 14. You may want to start work on it to help you prepare for the midterm.
I deal with appeals at the end of the date range for each assignment, so that I can look at them all together.

Lecture next week:

the remainder of MANOVA (quickly, since there are only a few new ideas in the second example)
repeated measures

Worksheets:

My solutions to worksheet 7 are up on the worksheets page.
Worksheet 8 is also up on the worksheets page.


2025-02-26 10:30: if you are appealing an assignment mark, you need to note the dates between which appeals are accepted: starting tomorrow for Assignment 3, starting Friday for Assignment 5. Any appeals already submitted for these assignments are too early, and will need to be re-submitted at the right time.
2025-02-25 14:20: assignment 5 is graded. Appeals between Feb 28 and Mar 7 by the usual process, which is:

send me an email with the word “appeal” and the course and assignment number in the subject header between the appropriate dates
explain precisely which question on the assignment has been incorrectly graded according to my solutions/the rubric, and how your answer is correct.
“my answer is the same as the solutions” is not persuasive, because the grader clearly thought it was not.
the appeal process is for correcting errors. I will not overturn a grader’s judgement (eg. about part marks).

2025-02-24 10:35: Assignments:

Assignment 3 is graded. Any appeals between Feb 27 and Mar 6 inclusive by the usual process.
Assignment 4 and 5 grading is under way.
Assignment 6 is open, and is due on Friday (Feb 28).

2025-02-20 14:20: we appear to have a Thursday update this week:

Assignment 6 is due on Feb 28 (Friday of the first week back after reading week)
My solutions to Assignments 4 and 5 are up on the assignment solutions page.
Grading of Assignments 3 and 4 is under way.
Next week’s lecture is on some or all of these, in this order:

contrasts (at the end of the ANOVA Revisited slides)
analysis of covariance
multivariate analysis of variance with link to discussion of Box M test

Whatever of these we get to is on the midterm; anything we don’t (which might be some of MANOVA) is not. There is a lecture the week of Mar 3, scheduled to be on repeated measures. This will not be on the midterm, but will be on the final exam (you can count on it), so miss it at your peril!
It is up to you to organize your own review for the midterm. I have twelve weeks of material to share with you, so we need to keep going.
The current draft of the midterm has 6 scenarios with a total of 30 questions, but that may change between now and the midterm date.
There is a Worksheet 7 up on the Worksheets page, which is on the material in next week’s lecture.
Looking ahead, Assignment 7 is not due until Mar 14 (so that you don’t have an assignment due the same day as the midterm), but starting it early will help you prepare for the midterm. It will open on Feb 28.

2025-02-14 11:45: Friday update:

next week is reading week! No lectures on Mon/Wed and no assignment due on Friday of reading week.
Assignment 5 is due tonight (open until Sun with late penalty).
Worksheet 6 solutions are up on the worksheets page.
Assignment 6, on this week’s material, is open but is not due until Feb 28.
When we come back from reading week, the Feb 24/26 lecture will be on some or all of:

contrasts (at the end of the ANOVA Revisited slides)
analysis of covariance
multivariate analysis of variance

Have a happy Family Day!

2025-02-11 16:30: weather forecast is calling for a snowstorm right after lecture ends tomorrow. Check the university status page to make sure that campus is open before you head in. If campus is closed there is, of course, no lecture, but if campus is open and the snowstorm is imminent, my contingency plan is to do lecture without a break and end early so that you can get home.

Edit 2025-02-12 12:30: contingency plan applies: we’ll go without a break and finish before 3:30 today. No office hours today, since I want to get home too! Catch me after class or post on the quercus discussion board if you have questions.

2025-02-07 15:30: a late Friday update this week, because I have been marking deferred exams:

Lecture next week is ANOVA revisited, including two-way ANOVA, interactions, simple effects, contrasts and the like.
On the worksheets page, solutions to worksheet 5 and questions for worksheet 6 (on the ANOVA stuff).
For extra practice on this material, see PASIAS chapter 31.
Assignment 4 is due tonight, and Assignment 5 is open.
Looking ahead a bit, Feb 17-21 is reading week; there are no lectures that week, and no assignment is due. (Assignment 5 is due just before reading week, and assignment 6 will not be due until the end of the week after reading week, ie. Feb 28). There will also be no assignment due the day of the midterm, and after that the worksheets and assignments will probably be out of sync number-wise.

2025-02-06 20:45: worksheet 5 solutions are up on the worksheets page. Assignment 5 opens at midnight.
2025-02-03 15:15: On Assignment 4 question 5, if you cannot get step to work for you without giving an error message: show the error message in the work you hand in (you will probably also need to add #| error: true as the top line of the code chunk in question), and then proceed in question 6 as if the best model has bill length, bill depth, and sex in it (if step does not work for you, you will need to explicitly fit this model in order to obtain predictions later).
2025-02-03 12:15: Assignment update:

Assignment 4 is open.
Assignment 3 is closed and solutions are posted on the assignment solutions page.
Assignment 2 is marked. Appeals by usual process between Feb 6 and Feb 13 inclusive.

2025-01-31 14:30: Friday update:

Midterm date, time, and place is official. See the announcement on Quercus for details. (I am not sharing details with anyone outside the class, for your safety.) Material is probably up to the week before the midterm, but it is too soon to say specifically what that will be.
Lecture next week on survival analysis.
Worksheet 4 solutions and worksheet 5 questions are up on the worksheets page.
For extra practice on survival analysis, see Chapter 30 of PASIAS.
Assignment 3 is due tonight (open until Sunday night), and assignment 4 is open now.

2025-01-27 11:00: Assignment 2 is closed. My solutions are on the assignment solutions page. The cold is improving, though I still have a cough. Assignment 3 is open.
2025-01-24 14:30: Friday update:

we have a tentative midterm date of March 7. I will let you know when this is official, though it is not likely to change.
next week’s lectures on:

the rest of logistic regression, that is to say the odds and ends at the end of the brand-preference example.
dates and times, possibly also including durations, intervals, and periods.
The reason for looking at dates and times now is to prepare us for survival analysis, which is the study of the time until an event happens.

worksheets, on the worksheets page:

solutions to #3 are up (thanks to the student who reminded me)
worksheet #4 is up, which will make sense after next week’s lecture (though in fact you may be able to do some of it now).

assignments:

#2 due tonight, open until Sunday night
#3 opened today, and is due on Friday of next week. Reminder that each assignment is based on the worksheet with the same number.


2025-01-23 15:30: Assignment 1 is graded, and I am about to release the marks. Appeals by the same procedure as STAC32 between Jan 26 and Feb 2 inclusive: that is to say, for your appeal to be successful, you will have to demonstrate that your work was graded inconsistently with my solutions and the rubric (see next sentence). This time, the grader created a rubric that you can see, which will also help to explain why you earned the mark you did (as well as making the grading quicker and more consistent).
2025-01-22 11:55: my cold continues. I did about 90 minutes of class on Monday before running out of energy, and I expect today to be about the same. On Monday, I went more or less straight home after class and took a nap, and I may need to do the same today. So, don’t count on finding me in my office after class today; if you have questions, ask me after lecture, or put them on the Quercus discussion board.
2025-01-20 11:35:

I have a cold. Try not to get too close to me this week. I feel as if I am running at half speed. Anyway, we will get to where we get. If I am out of juice, we may end early this week. Curiously, the material on worksheet 3 and assignment 3 is only about the first half of what I was planning to do this week, so it is actually OK if we don’t get as far as I had originally planned.
Solutions to Assignment 1 (which is now closed) are on the assignment solutions page.

2025-01-17 14:20: we appear to be on a Friday update this week. To add to the earlier reminders:

worksheet 2 solutions on the worksheets page; assignment 2 opens today.
next week’s lecture on the second half of logistic regression, starting with the coal-miners example. There is some stuff about odds ratios and relative risk that I may or may not talk about; also, my recollection is that the second half of logistic regression takes a while to work through because there is a fair bit of detail. There is a worksheet 3 already up on this stuff; for further examples and practice, see PASIAS chapter 28 (also, maybe chapter 29, depending on how far we get).

2025-01-13 11:15: some reminders:

worksheet 1 solutions are on the worksheets page.
assignment 1 is open, due on Friday (Jan 17) on the same material as Worksheet 1. My solutions to it will go up after it closes.
this week’s lecture on logistic regression, up until about the stuff on odds and log-odds.

more practice problems in PASIAS chapter 27.
assignment 2 will open on Friday Jan 17 and will be due on Friday Jan 24.

2025-01-09 12:20: it feels rather strange to say that week 1 is done, but for me it is. A couple of reminders:

worksheet 1, on the worksheets page, is available for practice on the stuff we did in class this week. I will post my solutions in the same place tonight (if I remember) or tomorrow (if I don’t). (If the worksheets display in an odd order, use the pulldown above the list of files to display them in file name order.)
assigment 1, on Quercus, opens tomorrow and is due on Jan 17 (at 11:59pm).
next week’s lecture: approximately the first half of logistic regression.

2025-01-05 20:00: Sunday update (not sure yet whether this will be a regular thing):

classes start Monday (section 2), Wednesday (section 1), place and time in Acorn
this week, course outline that is very similar to C32’s, some multiple regression stuff that is partly review and partly some new ideas. Some of the more review-y stuff I will speed through or skip depending how we’re doing for time.
there is a worksheets page that has the questions for a Worksheet 1 that will make sense after this week’s class.
see the Dec 30 note for when things will open and be due.
looking a bit further ahead, week 2 will be the first half or so of logistic regression. This is long; expect the second half of this to be in week 3.

2024-12-30 12:45: what to expect:

Course outline. Expect this course to be more about the statistics, taking for granted that you understand well the R stuff we learned in C32.
My plans for the course (google sheet), subject to change as we go. There will be a midterm to add once we know when it is. Specifically:

Lecture section 1 is on Wed afternoon, lecture section 2 is on Monday afternoon, beginning the week of Jan 6. There is one two-hour lecture a week (with a 10-minute break in the middle).
There is no tutorial in this course. Instead, I am expecting you to spend time on your own working through the week’s worksheet. Each worksheet should be available by Monday, and should make sense to you after your lecture for the week.
Worksheet solutions will be published on Fridays.
Assignments will open on Fridays and will be due the following Friday night. As in C32, expect there to be eight assignments, best six count. The first assignment will open at the end of week 1 and will be due at the end of week 2.
There will be no assignment due close to the midterm date (whenever that is), and so the last assignment will probably be due in the last or second-last week of March.


2024-12-09 14:45: Here’s where this year’s news is going to end up. We have a Quercus page. Lectures begin on Wed Jan 8 (section 1) and Mon Jan 6 (section 2). See Acorn for locations and times.

2024-04-25 15:00: all done, and grades submitted. They will reach you about two business days after being approved.

My solutions as they stand now.

2024-04-10 17:55: Exam off for printing. It finished up as 7 questions with 40 parts and 87 points (I took a couple of things out). there is nothing on log-linear models as promised
anything else from the course (that appeared in lectures) is fair game, with an emphasis on the material we talked about after the midterm
there are currently 7 questions with a total of 42 parts worth a total of 90 points

2024-04-01 12:15: the last Monday update:

I will let you know when assignments 7 and 8 are marked.
the last tutorial this afternoon, with something on principal components and something (maybe) on maps.
a note that leaflet maps and pdf don’t go well together (leaflet maps are actually html), so look at the html notes and PASIAS chapter for the stuff on maps.
lecture this week: the end of principal components, factor analysis, log-linear models. (The last is like regression, but for tables of frequencies. The technique is new, but the ideas should be mainly familiar. I think this is a nice way to end the course.)
Extra practice problems: PASIAS chapters 41 and 42. (We are not doing multidimensional scaling this time.)

Tutorial this afternoon, with something on cluster analysis.
Lecture this week: drawing maps, principal components.

2024-03-18 11:00: Monday update:

2024-03-13 16:30: before I forget, from today’s class, loading MASS like this:


library(MASS, exclude = "select")

loads the whole of MASS except for the one troublesome function select that gets tangled up with the tidyverse select, and if you load MASS this way, you don’t have to worry about the conflicted stuff. (You can also use include to say “load only these functions and no others”, which is in the same spirit as the Python from x import y).

2024-03-13 11:20: my solutions to assignment 6.
2024-03-11 10:30: Monday update:

The midterm is marked. Stats: Q1 32 (60%), median 38 (72%), Q3 43 (81%). I will be sharing the marks and the marked midterms shortly. The marks will be on Quercus, and you will be receiving an email from Crowdmark with instructions to see your marked exam.

Appeals are the same procedure as for assignments, between Mar 14 and Mar 21 inclusive. Do not expect me to overrule the grader’s judgment; thus, the only thing worth appealing is an actual grading error, such as an answer where the grader didn’t mark something relevant that you wrote, after consideration of my solutions and any comments on your exam. If you have not received full marks on a question part, you should have received a comment on your exam, or it should be obvious from my solutions what is missing or in error, or both of those things. Your appeal must include a clear description of the grading error (not grading judgment). If you appeal a grading judgment, you run the risk that I regrade your whole exam and your mark may go down as well as up. My philosophy on appeals is similar to that of Jeff Rosenthal.

Assignment 6 was due last night, and is open until Tuesday night (with late penalty). Assignment 7 opens tonight.
Tutorial this afternoon on zoom, with something on repeated measures.
Lecture this week: discriminant analysis, and if we have time, a start on cluster analysis.
Extra practice problems on this week’s lecture material: PASIAS chapter 35, and Chapter 36 if we get to cluster analysis this week (which I think is unlikely).

2024-02-22 11:50:

As I think I mentioned at the end of the last lecture, coverage for the midterm includes the last lecture before reading week (the “ANOVA revisited” stuff, as much as we saw in class).
The midterm has gone for printing. It has five questions, with a total of 23 parts worth 53 points altogether. Expect to be doing more explanation than coding (since the focus of this course is the understanding of the statistics).
The exam is open book, same rules as STAC32, and with the same expectation that you will organize your materials before the exam (or else you can expect to run out of time).
Suggestion: bring a calculator to the exam (an actual calculator, not your phone). You might find it helpful in a couple of places.
There will be a lecture next week before the midterm. That material will not be on the midterm, but you can count on it being on the final exam (and it will help you understand what follows in the course).
re Assignment 2, I have asked the grader to add some explanation to the grading so that you know where you didn’t get full marks. In the meanwhile, compare your answers with my solutions. The same applies to Assignment 3 and Assignment 4 that you don’t have back yet.

I plan to pick a problem from PASIAS to talk about, and of course bring other questions if you have them.
in lecture this week, some or all of:

log-odds and odds ratios and relative risk (partly in response to last week’s question about what those slope and intercept numbers actually mean)
logistic regression with a multi-category response when the response categories are ordered (the coal miners lung disease example)

2024-01-15 11:15: on the agenda this week:

tutorial today at 4:00pm, on zoom (link in Quercus announcement), on the regression stuff we did in lecture last week.
The stuff in the slides that I didn’t talk about is regression review. Read through those if you feel you need more review.
Assignment 1 opens tonight, is due next Sunday night (the 21st), on the stuff we did in lecture last week.
This week’s lecture is on logistic regression. The thing that distinguishes this from regular regression is that the response variable is categorical rather than quantitative. There are three parts (that we won’t do all of this week): when the outcome is a success/failure, when the outcome is several categories but ordered, when the outcome is several categories that are not ordered. There are also variations in how the data come to us (and therefore how we have to deal with it).
Next week’s tutorial (the 22nd) is on the stuff in this week’s lecture, and Assignment 2 (opens on the 22nd and is due on the 28th) is on the same material.

2024-01-08 12:45: Our course begins this week:

expect things to be structured a lot like they were in C32.
one two-hour lecture a week, on Wednesdays (I will give you a break in the middle). Your ACORN has the location.
one hour of tutorial-slash-office hour on Mondays, starting next week, probably on zoom. You can also catch me after lecture, or post in the Quercus discussions.
weekly assignments, with the first one going out on January 15 (out Monday night, due the following Sunday night), in the same style as for C32.
D29 is more about the statistics and less about the coding than C32 was; you will be learning some statistical methods that are definitely new to you, and I will assume that you are keeping up with the coding part.

2024-01-03 11:00: lecture 1 is a week away:

Quercus page is up (for assignments, discussion board etc)
be ready to learn some new statistics (there will be stuff you haven’t seen before)
I will assume that you are familiar with the R stuff, and the statistical ideas, that you learned in C32. (If you are not, be prepared to do some catching up.)
we begin with some new ideas in regression.
I don’t think there is anyone taking the course as STA 1007 (graduate course) this year; if you are, let me know.

2023-12-12 18:30: a bit more detail:

lectures are once a week on Wednesdays for 2 hours
there is a “practical” on Mondays at 4, starting in week 2, probably on zoom. This is a sort of combined office hour / tutorial to which you can bring questions about the previous week’s material.
weekly assignments (that you are used to from C32), opening Monday night, due the following Sunday night.
a 2-hour midterm and a 3-hour final as usual, on dates to be announced.

title: Programs and Courses
text: I am Supervisor of Studies for the Statistics Applied Minor program. FAQ. This program is intended for students in some Major or Specialist other than Mathematics, Statistics, or Computer Science (examples: Psychology, Health Studies), and provides a conceptual and computational overview of some intermediate and advanced statistical methods. The program is intended to be combined with a Major or Specialist program in some other field with a quantitative component, for which an applied knowledge of statistical methods will be an advantage.

title: Programs and Courses
text:
My courses

STAC32 Applications of Statistical Methods. For students with a second non-mathematical statistics course such as UTSC’s STAB27. Part of the Statistics Applied Minor program. Calendar entry.
STAC33 Introduction to Applied Statistics. For students with a second mathematical statistics course such as UTSC’s STAB57. Calendar entry.
STAD29 Statistics for the Life and Social Sciences. Advanced statistical methods from a how-to point of view. Part of the Statistics Applied Minor program. Calendar entry.
